Posts.Content: Gina - The radiation oncologist asked that he get the colonoscopy. He had it done (with no problems) which would have been about 6 weeks post op. Unfortunately, we got nowhere with the phone calls back and forth to MD Anderson. We're almost to Houston and will finish the drive there tomorrow - we have an appointment with the radiation oncologist Tuesday morning. We were told that the radiologist was not going to order any scans at this time and that we could leave after the appointment. I don't understand why they are not having a bone scan done. I have two pages of questions and hope to have them all answered and the doctor's action plan as to what the future holds before we head back to IL.
Posts.Title: Treatment after prostatectomy showing lymph node metastases

Posts.Content: I had robotic prostatectomy in February 2015. 1 of 3 lymph nodes positive for metastases, extra capsular extension identified, Gleason 7 (4+3). My oncologist referred me to a radiation oncologist for adjuvant radiation therapy. My 7-week post-op PSA is 0.0. I've had no scans done as yet, and the radiation oncologist said he's not ordering any at this time. I'm not sure what the plan is . . . he said I didn't need to plan on staying for any length of time after my office visit which tells me he isn't planning any radiation. Not sure I'm going to make this 1,000 mile trip for an office visit. Would like to hear from others with similar findings as me about how they proceeded with treatment. The lymph node involvement has me extremely worried. Thank you! 2010 - PSA 4.2 2011 - PSA 3.8 2012 - PSA 5.1 2013 - PSA 4.11 2014 - PSA 5.11 (Oct. 2014) - age 63 10/30/14 - Prostate ultrasound and biopsy - adenocarcinoma in 8 of 12 cores 2/11/15 - Performed in Illinois - daVinci prostatectomy with bilateral nerve preservation and bilateral pelvic lymph node dissection. Total Gleason Score 7 (3+4); Extra prostatic extension absent; Seminal vesicle invasion not identified; margins uninvolved by invasive carcinoma; lymph-vascular invasion present; perineural invasion present. Primary Tumor - pT2c Regional Lymph Nodes - pN1 (2/2 left nodes negative and 1/1 right node positive for metastatic prostatic adenocarcinoma 3/4/15 - consultation w/ oncologist at MD Anderson in Houston, TX Upgraded pathology to Gleason 7 (4+3) and Extra prostatic extension identified. Referred to radiation oncologist at MD Anderson. 4/1/15 - PSA 0.0 (7 weeks post-op)
Posts.Title: Treatment after prostatectomy showing lymph node metastases

Posts.Content: Thanks for the warm welcome and for sharing your stories! I'm actually Rhonda (Steve's wife) - he doesn't use a computer! : ) With the lymph node metastases, decided to go to MD Anderson in TX (sister and cousin both live north of Dallas - cousin is a patient at MD Anderson and insisted he go there). MD requested tissue from biopsy and surgery and upgraded diagnosis from a Gleason 7 (3+4) to a Gleason 7 (4+3) and also identified extra prostatic extension. Not good news, but better to know what you're dealing with than not. The oncologist then referred him to a radiation oncologist there at MD. He requested a colonoscopy (which has been done - 5 polyps removed and all negative) and a 7-week post op PSA which came back 0.0. Well, we're 1,000 miles away and having difficulty trying to explain to this radiation oncologist that it's a hardship to make a trip there if it's just for a consult. But, car would be packed in an hour if scans or radiation would begin. hms03049's post is informative - would be nice if the radiation doctor would just tell us that over the phone so we'd know how to plan. Letsdothis - again, sounds like a waiting period might be standard procedure . . . Again, thanks to all of you for the info and supportive comments!

My oncologist referred me to a radiation oncologist for adjuvant radiation therapy. My 7-week post-op PSA is 0.0. I've had no scans done as yet, and the radiation oncologist said he's not ordering any at this time. I'm not sure what the plan is . . . he said I didn't need to plan on staying for any length of time after my office visit which tells me he isn't planning any radiation. Not sure I'm going to make this 1,000 mile trip for an office visit. Would like to hear from others with similar findings as me about how they proceeded with treatment. The lymph node involvement has me extremely worried. Thank you! 2010 - PSA 4.2 2011 - PSA 3.8 2012 - PSA 5.1 2013 - PSA 4.11 2014 - PSA 5.11 (Oct. 2014) - age 63 10/30/14 - Prostate ultrasound and biopsy - adenocarcinoma in 8 of 12 cores 2/11/15 - Performed in Illinois - daVinci prostatectomy with bilateral nerve preservation and bilateral pelvic lymph node dissection. Total Gleason Score 7 (3+4); Extra prostatic extension absent; Seminal vesicle invasion not identified; margins uninvolved by invasive carcinoma; lymph-vascular invasion present; perineural invasion present. Primary Tumor - pT2c Regional Lymph Nodes - pN1 (2/2 left nodes negative and 1/1 right node positive for metastatic prostatic adenocarcinoma 3/4/15 - consultation w/ oncologist at MD Anderson in Houston, TX Upgraded pathology to Gleason 7 (4+3) and Extra prostatic extension identified. Referred to radiation oncologist at MD Anderson. 4/1/15 - PSA 0.0 (7 weeks post-op)
Posts.Title: Treatment after prostatectomy showing lymph node metastases

Posts.Content: Hi Gina - back at our hotel after meeting with radiation oncologist this morning at MD Anderson. Here's our plan of action: 1) A second PSA will be done June 15 (2-1/2 months after the last one done on April 1 which showed 0.0) 2) Says with his PSA at 0, scans would not show anything 3) Wants incontinence to get some better (currently he only has stress incontinence) before radiation 4) Will combine HT with IMRT - Hormone shot is given one month before starting radiation (we can have those in our home town done by urologist) and then again every 3 or 4 months 5) Radiation will last about 6-1/2 weeks (5 days/week) Guess we sort of live PSA to PSA from now on . . . it's the waiting and wondering . . . guess we just need to learn to live with the unknown. Your husband's lymph nodes . . . only 1 of 21 nodes positive? Mine only had three nodes removed with 1 positive. Sure wish they would have removed more! I will be thinking of you both and hoping he gets a good post-op PSA.
